title: Will Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó be detained or arrested by Venezuelan authorities before 1 January 2021?
preds: Ten days remaining. In January the new parliament takes its seat and Guaidó loses his claim as interim president. The only thing I see is if Guaidó does anything to provoke or try to assume control prior to January 1

No need to bother any more, since Maduro's henchpersons cleaned up in the election.  I gather from the wording of the question that if he just mysteriously disappears or is murdered, it will be a No.   The latter is not a choice in the Q, and the former would only be a Yes if the MadMen go public.

Given that the Maduro government has a processes to oust him following the election to parliament, I don't think they will do anything prior to the new parliament being in session - unless he does something unexpected like trying to take control over the country somehow
There is still a small chance that this could happen, will reduce as time goes.

Slight drop. Splitting hairs really. I have gone to zero for most of these “will it happen this year” questions but the fallout from the recent elections there mean there is still a real risk the calculations change for Maduro

Staying somewhat elevated on this forecast in case Maduro (quickly) becomes (more) emboldened after his "elections". https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/12/06/juan-guaido-prepares-lose-seat-venezuela-freedom/ https://www.vox.com/2020/12/4/22152597/venezuela-election-juan-guaido-nicolas-maduro
Note to self: Go to 0% by the 10th: Venezuela's majority religion is Christianity. It would look particularly bad to do anything rash during or shortly before Christmas. Going to 0% here.

Keeping forecast slightly elevated for the moment as Guaidó is reportedly losing some (remaining) support https://www.france24.com/en/americas/20201204-venezuela-s-guaido-risks-political-irrelevance-as-maduro-eyes-poll-victory
25% is a bit high with only about a month remaining
Note to self: -2% each week for the next 5 weeks. https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2020/11/26/venezuelas-regime-will-win-the-legislative-election-by-a-lot

https://www.explica.co/nicolas-maduros-regime-seeks-that-the-next-national-assembly-makes-a-trial-against-the-opposition-juan-guaido/ /Will the 06 Dec National Assembly election be free and fair, or result in a streamlined body loyal to Maduro?
/The next Assembly will be installed on 05 January 2021, so whatever action they really take, it after this question's time frame.
/Will Guaido have to be present to be judged and possibly sentenced, or can they even proceed in his absence?
/I don't know where the president-elect actually is, or whether he is exile: in June 2020, he was allegedly hiding in the French embassy in Caracas, which the French foreign secretary denied days later. He was last (?) seen on the streets of Caracas also in June 2020 in a video statement, so obviously he hasn't left Venezuela for exile. https://www.theblockcrypto.com/linked/85319/crypto-firms-venezuela-guaido-coronavirus
He's somehow managed to maintain a public presence but he's endured.
If it was going to happen it would have happened
It would be very foolish to risk provoking Trump to do something rash.
Actually just dropping to 1 here for the remainder unless info comes out suggesting this could happen. So far doesn't seem like there's any intent to follow through on this.

Living Without CITGO: Why Venezuela May Lose Its Crown Jewel
https://www.caracaschronicles.com/2020/11/13/living-without-citgo-why-venezuela-may-lose-its-crown-jewel/
November 13, 2020 tl;dr: Guaidó's government in a dire financial situation. Note that as Guaidó's government runs out of money, this makes an arrest less likely.
done nothing up to now and time is running out
Given a Biden win, I doubt Maduro would want to bait a new president.

Passage of time update. Keeping the forecast elevated a bit until after the planned December parliamentary 'elections' https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-10-07/eu-rules-out-sending-observers-for-venezuela-vote

FYI - only tangentially related to question
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/oct/25/leopoldo-lopez-flees-venezuela-vowing-to-continue-fighting-maduro-regime
Chances of this happening seems more remote.
He’d probably love to be arrested or detained just to get some coverage.

The EU is not even bothering to send observers to the December election (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-eu-idUSKBN26S1DH). Maduro seems secure enough that, with the turmoil in the US, and with the opposition needing American support, it seems unlikely any action which would trigger detention could happen.

Very hard to put a number on this one, cannot see an obvious source for a prior. I think my initial view that there seemed to be little upside for Maduro in making an arrest at this point. Dropping slightly on passage of time, but also conscious that both us and Venezuelan elections could change the calculus for Maduro.
I could see a scenario where this happens but Maduro seems to have weathered the storm and this would be escalation.
Slight increase as tension mounts ahead of election
Updated to reflect lack of movement in that area.
People only believe what you tell them if you make no sense whatsoever.

Dropping further as time goes on. Lower than crowd because it's useful to have a symbol to blame problems on, such as an opposition opponent supported by the boogie man US. Hard to blame problems on them if they're in jail...

-2% While European courting of Guaidó continues [1], I see little eagerness for action until the 6th December elections. [1] He is going to be awarded the City of Athens Democracy Award at an (online) event, https://www.athensdemocracyforum.com/speakers

Maduro has released some of the less vocal opposition members from prison in preparation for upcoming elections in an attempt to mollify criticism of his regime.
The foreign secretary has invited representatives from UN and EU to monitor the December elections which would indicate a will for International recognition. Arrest of Juan Guaido would not help this.    https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-53985277 https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-09-07/venezuelas-guaido-calls-for-more-international-pressure-on-maduro

Highly unlikely given the remaining timeframe.  Parliamentary elections are scheduled to be held in Venezuela on 6 December 2020 and US already calls out they might be rigged by Maduro's regime. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-usa-sanctions/us-blacklists-venezuelan-lawmakers-alleging-election-manipulation-idUSKCN26D274
seems it would've happened already if it was likely.

Guaido appeared to be a "flash in the pan" in 2019.  He had his moments to topple Maduro but failed.  He is no longer a threat as the world's attention has turned to Covid-19 and the related economic slowdown.  Maduro would not be foolish enough to stir the pot but arresting Guaido.

Revising slightly upward — "Venezuela's Guaido calls for more international pressure on Maduro" https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/venezuelas-guaido-calls-for-more-international-pressure-on-maduro-idUSKBN25Y24M
From several thousand miles away, it appears that Guaido' has almost become irrelevant in daily affairs. It appears that Covid-19 is a much more formidable foe.
Time has passed and it doesn't seem like this threat has been renewed or is imminent. 1 in 10 chance seems appropriate.
Would be a grave miscalculation from Maduro - really don't think he will give the opposition such a gift to reignite.

A split in the opposition to Maduro reduces the power and legitimacy which Guaidó has. This cuts both ways, either Maduro will use this as an opportunity to arrest him now he has less friends, or Maduro can let Guaidó's support fizzle out into nothing and not bother with the man at all. While I'm inclined to believe that, as a dictator, he will eventually want revenge on Guaidó  for challenging him, I think this rift will occur after 2020 https://www.batimes.com.ar/news/latin-america/venezuelas-opposition-capriles-politician-breaks-with-us-backed-guaido.phtml
Cutting in half. It doesn't appear that he is a threat to Maduro at this time.

Guaidó isn't that popular anymore (both in Venezueala and abroad) it seems. I don't know whether that makes him more or less likely to be detained: an arrest may prompt people to rally behind him, but taking him out of the equation is easier than it was before. His chief of staff was arrested in March 2019, when polls had around 60% of the population recognizing him as acting president, but now "71.0% recognized Maduro as president, 23.7% saw neither as president, 3.0% recognized Guaidó as president and 2.2% did not know who to recognize as president" and "88.3% of respondents believed that Guaidó was incapable of governing Venezuela".  [1] [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Guaid%C3%B3#Polls The international threats associated with arresting him have diminished, but he's simply not a threat to Maduro - making me think detaining/arresting him just wouldn't be worthwhile.
Going down with the passage of time; 1% every week.
hard to say - all depends what he does. pandemic might occupy minds

Struggled to work out a base rate for this one. Maduro has not been afraid to make political arrests, including from the opposition (e.g. Roberto Marrero). However arresting Guaido would be a big step, and seems unnecessary at the moment - Maduro has a strong hold on power, and arresting Guaido would invite further pressure from countries such as the US. Maduro and Guaido have even been cooperating recently over the fight against COVID. On the other hand, things can change quickly, and with countries focused on COVID response, Maduro could see at as a good time to consolidate his power further.  The parliamentary elections in December, in which deputies will be elected to the National Assembly (controlled by Guaido), would have the potential to escalate the situation again, but they may not take place due to COVID. The main opposition parties announced they would boycott the elections. If these elections do take place, they could be another power-grab opportunity for Maduro.

"Guaidó has made few practical gains. The young opposition leader’s stake was further weakened following a calamitous attempt claimed by an American mercenary, Jordan Goudreau, to force Maduro from office. The plot was quickly foiled, arrests were made, and Maduro came out looking in control ... Maduro has managed to strengthen his grip on the country’s institutions and political parties." https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/08/10/coronavirus-maduro-consolidating-control-venezuela/
Going down because of the passage of time.

Juan Gusaido had gained the upper hand in Venezuela by becoming the interim president and gaining the acceptance of the Western democratic governments and a level of popularity amongst the people.
The threat of his arrest was probably at its zenith in February and threatened by Maduro.
Due to a lack of action , this popularity has been waning with his acceptance by the public of his presidency going form 49% in February to 36% in June.
Since April Maduro and the Supreme court have accused the opposition of treason and conspiracy without retaliation from the International community.
This may have given Maduro some respite from Gusaido, the figure head of the opposition.
The onset of Covid-19 has come into play by getting Maduro and Gusaido to come together in a joint effort to raise funds to fight the pandemic, given the IMF’s refusal to offer funds to combat the virus due to a lack of clarity as to who is the recognised president. The presidency standoff has therefore had to be stalled to combat the pandemic.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/02/venezuela-maduro-arrest-juan-guaido-200214185506708.html  https://reliefweb.int/report/venezuela-bolivarian-republic/venezuela-rulings-threaten-free-and-fair-elections  https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2020/06/25/how-venezuelas-regime-plans-to-win-this-years-legislative-election?frsc=dg%7Ce  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-analysis/disappointed-venezuelans-lose-patience-with-guaido-as-maduro-hangs-on-idUSKCN1TW3ME  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/venezuela-top-court-ousts-leaders-of-guaidos-party-ahead-of-vote-idUSKBN24833G  https://www.dailysabah.com/world/americas/venezuelas-maduro-guaido-agree-to-join-forces-in-covid-19-fight  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/22/venezuela-maduro-guaido-coronavirus-secret-talks  https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/imf-rules-out-covid-19-loan-to-venezuela/1770442
This situation is starting to stalemate. the regime, knowing Guaido's status with the EU and US, and is playing the game of allowing him to maintain as a token Opposition force.

To me it is glaringly obvious that if Guaido were going to be arrested, it would have already happened. If he were to be arrested the situation in Venezuela would be pushed completely out of control, and Maduro would most likely lose the support of the military.
The pandemic gives greater powers to government, and it's possible they will indicate Guiado is impeding the national effort..
He is not their elected leader

Warrant exists. But for some time now so it doesn’t mean much. Botched Maduro murder attempt seems to have empowered him (Maduro, that is). But UK court just recognized Guaido as formal president of Venezuela in UK’s eyes. This means nothing much for Maduro of course, but still protects Guaido in the eyes of the eyes of public opinion, making it rather “costly” for Maduro to go ahead and seize Guaido. I would say for Maduro to arrest Guaido is quite unlikely, but not outright fantasy. I would assign a 25% if there was no time limit, but given the January 2021 deadline of the question, I will reduce it to 15%.
Considerable pressure on all sides. Difficult to predict.

Revising the forecast down because other governments have recognised Guaido.  Which ups the stakes if anything happens to him.  With Covid focus is also elsewhere, but that is the same for other countries.  Guaido is still a risk to Maduro.  A detention or arrest, even as a symbol, especially if the election is lost, is still quite high.

I have been following the question for some time, and Guaido's arrest always seemed imminent, except that it never happened. I am therefore adjusting quite strongly to compensate for previous exposure. "Cutting my losses".

Bumping the "Yes" bracket on the back of news that the Venezuelan Supreme Court has suspended the leadership of Guaido's party.  If this is true, he is now acting in defiance of a court order by engaging in politics. May bump it further once there's more information on repercussions for a breach.   https://reliefweb.int/report/venezuela-bolivarian-republic/venezuela-rulings-threaten-free-and-fair-elections
I'll join @Hammer-Time in the cellar on this one.

Juan who? No sense making a martyr out of a failure.
https://www.economist.com/node/21788594?frsc=dg%7Ce

Next election date 6 December 2020.
If the Maduro regime will not have detained or arrested Juan Guaidó by that date, he will probably build the next legitimate government of Venezuela.
What is the forcing function for this. Maduro in control, why cause a fuss?

Noone strong enough to resist current leader
How to save a country without interfering?
The fight for control of the national assembly will result in jail time for the opposition leaders.

Reasons
1. Maduro needs to show that he is in control, and like all strong man need to act to control the  "enemy" Guaido.
2. Guaido needs to stay in the game and will act to provoke a reaction which he has not done now for a few months.
3. Both parties need to escalate the "conflict". between them, and therefore a detention or arrest is in both parties interest and therefore likely to happen. Only question is when. 
4. The 6 months timeline makes it more likely than not.

Some additional external factors: COVID-19 and global recession has piled more pressure on Maduro. People under pressure tend to over-react. The courts have handed Maduro control of two prominent opposition party before the upcoming elections. If Guaidó feels forced into a corner and plans ever more desperate measures, there is an increased possibility Maduro is waiting for just such an opportunity to act.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/venezuelas-maduro-takes-over-rival-political-parties-11592348738
It makes no sense to arrest someone who is so incapable of mounting a credible challenge.
tail risk but so much irrationnal behavior that you can`t discount it
He will not be detained by Venezuelan authorities, he might be missing and never found, but it will never official. But I think he sticks it out and becomes president.
Covid-19. Next year, he’s going to be in trouble.
If he stirs things up too much and Maduro feels the US and others are more concerned with other issues, he would move to arrest him.
Probably not due to concentration of power during the pandemic.

Maduro may not yet be ready to engage the wrath of the Trump administration arresting or detaining the man who they feel is the rightful President of Venezuela. In fact, Venezuela may need to ask for assistance from the US due to the increasing number of COVID-19 cases and the low oil prices which will both have a severe impact upon the country. This does not mean that Maduro has forgotten about a failed coup attempt involving Guaido aides. His patience, as well as pragmatism, probably will not last the year.
COVID related issues will make it hard for this to occur.
Negative Covid effect may force Maduro to create a distraction.

Such an arrest would lose Maduro his remaining support in the international community and would be exceedingly stupid. Maduro can maintain power if he does not draw attention to himself, given the current pandemic and civil unrest, particularly in the US.

Looks like they're trying to take them down. "Three politicians that support Leopoldo López and Juan Guaidó, have withdrawn from their “functions” in the last hours."
"Last May, a request for interpretation was introduced before Venezuelan Supreme Court of Justice that seeks to determine if Voluntad Popular has become a terrorist organization, given its proven link to illegal, violent and unpatriotic acts promoted by Leopoldo López and Juan Guaidó.
It is unknown if the possibility that the organization might lose its character as a political group and be permanently outside the law, is related to the resignation of these and other members who have decided to abandon ship."
https://orinocotribune.com/fearing-justice-or-ridicule-more-politicians-distancing-from-lopez-and-guaido/

The question is will they capture him?  „Days ago, Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has referred to Juan Guaidó on at least three occasions as “the fugitive from justice” in public addresses, which has caused many debates among his followers because there is no official announcement about warrants for his arrest” orinocotribune.com/juan-guaido-is-protected-by-the-french-embassy-in-caracas/amp/

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/06/venezuela-maduro-joins-hands-guaido-fight-virus-200603103335964.html "The government of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and opposition leader Juan Guaido have reached an agreement to cooperate to raise funds for the fight against the coronavirus." This will reduce the chances of detainment in the short term.
Apparently he is now in the French Embassy

In Spanish language newspapers: The arrest of Vicente Borjas intensifies the persecution of the Maduro government against the environment of Juan Guaidó.  Borjas was taken by the FAES along with his family this Friday night and was later released in the late hours of this Saturday.
 Caracas.  This Friday at night, Vicente Borjas, a member of the work team of Juan Guaidó, president of the AN and in charge of the Republic, along with his family, was arrested by members of the Police Special Actions Forces (FAES)  Bolivarian National (PNB).
 The arrest of Borjas, which lasted for almost a day before his subsequent release, was denounced by Guaidó himself through his account on the social network Twitter, and represents another case of a member of the parliamentarian's direct environment who, from the  In 2019, they have been irregularly detained by members of the security forces loyal to Nicolás Maduro. The opposition legislative majority ratified Juan Guaidó as president of the Venezuelan Parliament on Thursday, calling a sentence of the supreme court of the Chavista line "illegal", which endorsed Luis Parra, a rival of the leader, as head of the National Assembly  opponent.
(News of context: How is Guaidó after the Supreme Court's decision to annul his presidency?)
 "I will continue to exercise my functions," said Guaidó at a press conference, after a session. The TSJ ruling coincides with negotiations to elect a Supreme Electoral Council (CNE) with a view to parliamentary elections scheduled for this year, around which no progress has been reported.  "The reactivation of the nominations committee (for the CNE) will depend on the political climate," Guaidó said Thursday, stressing that the Legislative is investigating Parra and his allies for alleged bribes.  On Tuesday, Parra summoned that committee to resume the talks.
Upshot: It sounds like Guaido has some power and they are not taking him on directly.

https://www.abc.es/internacional/abci-supremo-venezolano-anula-presidencia-parlamentaria-juan-guaido-202005270152_noticia.html
Note that right now Venezuela has two Supreme Courts; it's the one which Maduro controls the one which has condemned him.
The PMC arrests did not lead to an escalation.

A little higher as Maduro’s wife said that despite Guido saying he had nothing to do with an operation to kidnap Maduro he is still subject to arrest. The mercenaries had a recording of and a signed contract with Guido. Guido says that is all Doctored evidence. If it does not happen soon then probably not.
https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/05/12/venezuela-arrests-40-suspected-nicolas-maduro-kidnap-plot/ Rhetoric and aggression from Maduro's camp is ramping up. Changing from 35%.

His deputy and chief of staff have already been arrested - he has clearly lost some internal support although the international "support" still exists. His arrest would escalate the situation and invite more involvement from the international community, specifically the US. Arresting the internationally recognized leader would be crossing a dangerous line, hence they have been trying to weaken support by arresting his close allies vs. Guaido himself. Another interesting development is where the Venezuelan army stands: currently they have the ability to change allegiance but as of mid-May they stand with Maduro. 
https://tass.com/world/1057106
"Detained" is one reason I'll keep the forecast up a bit, at least for now..  https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/in-venezuela-americans-attempt-to-stage-a-bay-of-piglets
Authorities will give it a try, but Guaidó has many foreign supporters and receives aid and protection.

The latest coup attempt gives Maduro justification for an arrest. However, Guaido is currently sheltering in a European embassy. There are a lot of priors that I need to establish. How willing is Maduro to break international tradition and seize someone at an embassy? Why has Guaido been seized yet? What reasons compel Guaido to leave the embassy?

https://nation.com.pk/08-May-2020/venezuela-s-opposition-leader-guaido-taking-refuge-in-european-embassy-after-coup-attempt Venezuela's opposition leader Guaido is taking refuge in a European embassy, reducing the chances of an arrest in the short term. However, If he leaves, he will surely be arrest upon exit. This could be a win-win for Maduro. Diminishing Guaido's influence without the need to cross any of the USA's 'red lines' (aka arrested). However, Guaido will face a choice between fading into irrelevancy or risking everything. After a cool-off period he may continue his campaign for leadership. Future civil unrest due to coronavirus + the economy + shortages may give Guaido a false sense of security, leading to an exit from the embassy and consequently his arrest.    Overall I think his chances of arrest/detainment have increased. But not before Jan 1 2021. Changing from 27% to 35%. Criticism very welcome!
One news report that Guaido is currently "taking refuge in a European embassy" to avoid arrest: https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/venezuela-guaido-taking-refuge-in-european-embassy-/1831626
Updating 15% -> 25%, as per the Bay of Pigs sequel. Current forecast of 35% still seems way too high.

Updated, due to PMC activity in recent weeks. This incident has the potential to be connected to Guaido which could lead to his arrest.  https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/2-u-s-mercenaries-arrested-after-raid-in-venezuela

Previous forecast:
19% Jordan Goudreau, a former Army Green Beret, said he directed a secret military operation with the backing of Venezuela opposition leader Juan Guaido in the anti-Maduro coup called "Operation Gideon"

The soldier may have been forced to make a false confession, but either way, this accusation will increase the likelihood of Guaido being arrested.
Looks like COVID-19 might unite the Maduro and Guaido. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/22/venezuela-maduro-guaido-coronavirus-secret-talks
Guaido is still a public figure and Maduro needs an "enemy".
Odds go up with Covid-19 as it sets pretense for emergency measures and distracts the international community.
I think this is becoing increasingly likely as the world is distracted by Covid19 and it's aftermath.

CoVid stresses on all levels of Venezuelan could cause more destabilization.
Cutting forecast in half, no news just mysery.
Passage of time + C19 = lowered odds
Venezuela is increasingly unstable, C19 stress can cause anything.

Rumors of "exploratory" talks between Maduro and Guaido allies. May not arrest or detain him (Guaido) just now.. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/venezuela-government-opposition-begin-secret-talks-amid-coronavirus-pandemic-sources-n1188941
Continued US saber rattling, pressure upon pressure, no telling where things will burst.

The factions have reportedly started quiet low-level talks.  Not a good move to put the leader of the opposition in the slammer just now.  Later, when the talks break down, it's more likely. I notice the question doesn't contemplate that Guaido may be killed.  I suppose that would make this a No, although it seems counter to the apparent intent of the Q.
Would estimate relatively more likely than not in next 9 months.
Could be, would be easy to order arrest of someone now, even just for breaching social distancing rules.

Not one I know a lot about, bit of a placeholder. However, certainly seems possible, and looks like Maduro wants it to happen theoretically, but in reality I expect there are a lot of ways of the crisis playing out in both directions without an arrest.

In February 2020 Maduro said that Guaido “will be in jail for all the crimes he’s committed”. Guaido arrived back in Venezuela 3 days before that statement and he was not arrested or detained. Maduro said “that day hasn’t come yet… But it will come”. Apparently, he is waiting for Venezuela’s justice system to decide that Guaido should be imprisoned. 

Fast forward to last month, State prosecutors in Venezuela have summoned Guaido for an attempted coup d’état, adding to the long list of legal cases against Guaido. Despite this, he has never been arrested and I doubt this case alone will change his chances of arrest or detainment in the short term. 

The incentive to arrest or detain Guaido peaked last year and was matched by the opportunity to do so. A shattered economy, multiple protests, and snowballing support for Guaido put pressure on Maduro to act. He did not arrest or detain him because it would have been political suicide. 

Maduro will know that arresting/detaining Guaido in the middle of huge protests would add fuel to the fire. It would bolster his support and portray him as the oppressed anti-Maduro figurehead to Venezuelans. Furthermore, the United States has warned Maduro that arresting Guaido would be his “last mistake”. 

In my opinion Venezuela is about to go through some extraordinarily turbulent times, starting imminently. COVID-19, the oil crisis (including Rosneft stopping operations in Venezuela), inflation, emigration, and sanctions will desecrate its economy even further. If past trends continue this will trigger mass protests. This means the arrest or detainment of Guaido would be unlikely. 

However, Maduro may believe that arresting Guaido will prevent protests from growing in intensity. It may even get to a point where he has nothing to lose. Maduro tried to consolidate his power recently (extrajudicial killings) and may feel that the repercussions of actions are now smaller. There could be an accidental arrest or an arrest that has not been authorised by Maduro. A protest is a perfect environment for this. Furthermore, Guaido may commit a serious criminal offense by the end of this year which leads to his arrest or detainment. 

Guaido is backed very strongly by the United States. If there is intelligence that an arrest is imminent, he may be granted asylum or some form of protection. However, a previous assassination attempt showcased his vulnerability to such events. 

The new $15 million bounty for information resulting in Maduro's arrest slightly increases the chances of him vacating office. This would drastically reduce the chances of Guaido being detained.

Overall, I believe arresting or detaining Guaido would be very damaging to Maduro. A skilled and experienced political player such as himself will surely know this. However, if the legal case against Guaido starts to intensify it would increase the chances of arrest. An unauthorized arrest/mistake is a possibility, but it is unlikely. Maduro has been in many very difficult situations before and always seems to find a way to survive. However, the current unprecedented events may cause unexpected outcomes. Criticism is very welcome! https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/13/world/americas/venezuela-maduro-oil.html
https://www.nationalreview.com/2020/04/in-effort-to-oust-maduro-u-s-gives-maximum-pressure-a-new-meaning/

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/02/venezuela-maduro-arrest-juan-guaido-200214185506708.html

Back in 2019, it looked like Guaido could topple Maduro's regime, with the help of the US.  But Maduro survived.  With no quick win in sight, the Trump administration is losing interest in Venezuela.  Guaido is no longer a significant threat to Maduro.  Maduro will leave Guaido alone lest making him a martyr and re-ignite the interest of the US.   Furthermore, the economy of Venezuela appears to be reviving [1] with some moderate reforms.  There is no reason to rock the boat by arresting Guaido.  [1]  https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/01/world/americas/Venezuela-economy-dollars.html

~~~~~~
Base Rate
~~~~~~
Maduro has been in power since 2013, and since he has been in power he has detained a minimum of four people [1]. That would make it an average of about .8 of a person detained per year.  The prisoners of note being Leopolda Gomez, Caracas Mayor Antonio Ledezma, and someone else that I cannot find right now [2]. For context on them being in prison comes directly after they criticized Maduros authoritarian regime. However as a third note, there have only been three events that lead to four arrests. So I am going to focus on the events.  If we do some quick back of the envelope calculations, if there have been three arrest "events" over the last 7 years for major political players . That would lead me to think that there is approximate a 42% chance that  Maduro will arrest Guiado this year.   42% will be my baserate to start with.  ~~~~~~
Inside View
~~~~~~
Now we have to start answering some questions. AKA What will it take for this to happen.
1. Guado will have to be in Venezuala at some point or points this  year. 
2. Maduro will not have to care about international consequences if he does arrest Guado
3. There will have to be some in sighting incident  for Maduro to make a move to arrest Guado (perhaps it already has happened)
4. Venezula's improvement of the economy makes Guado irrelevant
5. People will still care about Guado 
6. International pressure drops off against Maduro ~~~~~~~
Conclusion
~~~~~~~
There are a lot of variables to consider for this question, many of which are difficult to quantify as of right now. However, most of the time, nothing will happen. Which will make me put my score down to 35%, but I think that the other questions should be researched and factored into make an accurate decision on what my percentage should be.  1. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/08/world/americas/venezuela-opposition-zambrano-detained.html

It's probably just bluster, but yesterday Maduro said that “the day will come” [1] when Venezuela's courts will order Guaido's arrest. It seems very plausible to me that Maduro has held off ordering Guaido's arrest until he can instead get a court to order his arrest. This way, Maduro can blunt any international criticism that would otherwise be directed his way as a consequence of Guaido's arrest.  However, this is a strategy that Maduro could have employed previously and he has thus far chosen not to. Hence, I still think it is more likely than not that Guaido will not be arrested in the time frame of this question - namely because the regime probably doesn't want to face the blowback from arresting Guaido - "it's unlikely Maduro would risk escalating international tension by detaining Guaido" [2]. My post from last week drew upon the fact that Guaido has been losing momentum from Venezuelan citizens due to two factors: 
1. Massive immigration into neighboring states
2. Maduro's international support from Cuba, China and Russia.  Recently, Guaido made an appearance at the State of the Union address which shows an increasing support from the United States. Even though this increased pressure and interest in supporting the opposition leader from the US does seem as if it could boost morale among protesters, I think that this is more of a gesture that the US president is using to secure support from his Latino constituents. Guaido has also been calling for more protests in order to put pressure on Maduro, however, I believe that the fear tactics of the Maduro regime have been putting more pressure on Guaido because people are starting to weigh their decisions based on their growing fears. With all of these combined factors, I will update my probability to 38% simply because protests have not been increasing, but Guaido's appearance at the State of the Union address could make Maduro view Guiado as more of a threat to his position of power.
